org.tantalum.util

Class LRUVector

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.util.Vector
      • org.tantalum.util.LRUVector

  • public class LRUVector
extends java.util.Vector
    Least recently used list of object Each object can be in the Vector a maximum of one time. Elements are always added to the end of the Vector so the oldest object is at position 0.

    • Field Summary

      • Fields inherited from class java.util.Vector

        capacityIncrement, elementCount, elementData

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      LRUVector()
      Create a new least-recently-used collection
      LRUVector(int length)
      Create a new least-recently-used collection, specifying the maximum size

      Modifier and Type Method and Description

      Check if the object is in the collection.
      void insertElementAt(java.lang.Object o, int index)
      Explicitly adding an element at a position is not allowed in an automatically-sorted collection like this.
      java.lang.Object removeLeastRecentlyUsed()
      Remove the element least recently accessed in the collection, thereby shrinking the size.
      void setElementAt(java.lang.Object o, int index)
      Explicitly setting an element at a position is not allowed in an automatically-sorted collection like this.

      • addElement

        public void addElement(java.lang.Object o)
        Add one element. If the element is already in the collection, it will be moved to the beginning (position 0).

      • setElementAt

        public void setElementAt(java.lang.Object o,
                int index)
        Explicitly setting an element at a position is not allowed in an automatically-sorted collection like this. This will always through IllegalArgumentException.
        Overrides:

      • removeLeastRecentlyUsed

        public java.lang.Object removeLeastRecentlyUsed()
        Remove the element least recently accessed in the collection, thereby shrinking the size.
        Returns:

      • contains

        public boolean contains(java.lang.Object o)
        Check if the object is in the collection. Note that this operation will also shift the object to position 0 as it counts as "use" and thus possible relevancy for access in least-recently-used algorithms.
        Overrides:
        contains in class java.util.Vector
